descript.abstract: Two core indicators are calculated from this test: the average surface stability value and the average sub-surface stability value. The percentage of the surface samples tested that are equal to 6 (very stable) is another useful indicator that is easy to calculate. Both are correlated with all three ecosystem attributes. Higher stability has been directly correlated with reductions in erosion. Reference(s): Herrick, J.E., J. Van Zee, S.E. McCord, J.W. Karl, E. Courtright, and L. Burkett. 2018. The Monitoring Manual for Grassland, Shrubland, and Savanna Ecosystems. USDA-ARS.
descript.purpose: The soil stability test is a relatively simple test that is sensitive to complex changes in physical, chemical and biological processes. These are the processes that glue soil particles together. Soil stability at different depths and under different types of vegetation can be used to reflect changes in organic matter cycling.
